instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT is PPBUS_G3H backlight voltage entering the backlight boost circuit once the transistor has been told to allow it through. .
definitions.LCDBKLT_FB: What is LCDBKLT_FB? LCDBKLT_FB is a feedback line between backlight output and the feedback pin on the LED driver. When this connection is broken, backlight output will be equal to PPBUS_G3H voltage of the system rather than boosting. Since this point is the highest voltage in the system, it is the fastest to corrode when liquid damaged, so it is a very common point to check when there is no backlight. .
definitions.I2C_BKLT_SDA: What is I2C_BKLT_SDA? I2C_BKLT_SDA is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..
definitions.EDP_BKLT_PWM: What is EDP_BKLT_PWM? EDP_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that only has image on external display.

Client said that it was listening music, and the display died.

Already tried 2 known good displays, with same result.

Not sure if the problem is backlight or image, but I can't see nothing on the display, even with a flashlight

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_BKLT_D</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_FET_DRV</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>ISNS_LCDBKLT_N</SIGNAL> = 13V
<SIGNAL>ISNS_LCDBKLT_P</SIGNAL> = 13V
<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_BKLT_A</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SENSE_OUT</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_FB</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> = 0V

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> starts at 0.150V and them drops to 0.050V.

Not sure if <DIODE>D8410</DIODE> is good, because voltage is passing through both pins (I think that in diode reading it only should have voltage in one way, correct?)

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message: Check HPD signal from video connector; with LCD assembly connected, of course.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL>?
Check voltage and diode on <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA lines.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Yes, I have 5V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL>.

<SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL>:
5V
0.508 diode reading

<SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL>:
4.5V
0.511 diode reading

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message: Check diode mode on J8500's EDP data lines.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Hi.

<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL> = OL
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_P</SIGNAL> = OL
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_N</SIGNAL><0> = OL
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_P</SIGNAL><0> = OL
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_N</SIGNAL><1> = OL
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_P</SIGNAL><1> = OL
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_N</SIGNAL><2> = OL
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_P</SIGNAL><2> = OL
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_N</SIGNAL><3> = OL
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_P</SIGNAL><3> = OL

<SIGNAL>BUF_EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> = 0.718
<SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> = 0.786

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
I forgot this board has series capacitors for data lines.
You should check on the other side of the capacitors.

"Not sure if <DIODE>D8410</DIODE> is good, because [B]voltage is passing through both pin[/B]s"
I'm not sure what this means...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Hi.

I'll try to explain what I mean:

When measuring the diodo <DIODE>D8410</DIODE> with the multimeter, and placing the positive tip on one of the diode pads (pad1), and the negative tip on the other diode pad (pad2), I think that current should only pass from one side of the diode (value reading in diode).

If I invert the position of the multimeter tips (the positive one on pad 2 of the diode and the negative one on pad 1), the diode reading should be 0.

This is not happening. Even reversing the test tips, I always have diode readings above 0.

Did I you understod? Is this thought correct? How do I test schottky diodos in a proper way?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Correct, if you test it out of board!
Onboard measuring is affected by other components.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
OK. I've mesured it onboard. That explain the reading. Out of board, I get the right reading.

However, it seams that I have a problem on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>, cause diodo reading is 0.105. I think it should be higher (dont have other board to compare it).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Is that without LCD connected?
Then should have a bad filter capacitor.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message:
Yes, it is with the board alone on the desk.

Can I inject voltage there?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no image
threads.message: You can, but probably need an IR camera to find the culprit.
